entry.title: Step Four: Have a Plan
entry.content:
The final step of #The Framework for Changing Habits, is to establish a plan of action to begin to shift your behavior.

The hardest part of of #habit change, even #equipped with the knowledge of your cue, is making the conscious effort to steer away from doing your #routine. Sometimes you forget and sometimes you just donâ€™t have the #Willpower to defy your urge. Hence, study after study concluded that having a plan is the easiest way to accomplish something. Not just having a plan in mind, itâ€™s as if writing in water, but having it in a piece of paper is more powerful.

Say, through #reward experimentations, your finding indicates you quench your to urge to eat something sweet by eating a chocolate bar. Also, you found out that a #working alternative is to bite an apple instead. Your plan of action should be: â€œWhenever I feel the need to take a chocolate bar, I will grab an apple instead.â€ Or better yet, if you know what time you usually snack, â€œAt 4:30, I will go to the cafeteria and grab a fruitâ€.

Specificity is key. The more you are specific with your plan, the easier it is to follow.

Additionally, plan ahead for when you succumbed to your urge. After all, we are just humans who act according to our urges. Itâ€™s how we survive. You may choose to punish yourself for it, better yet have a plan of action when you capitulate. For instance, instead of eating a fruit you grabbed a cookie. You may write â€œWhen I grabbed a cookie, I will only eat half of it.â€ Still, you satisfied your cue to eat something sweet but its still a #win because you resisted to eat the whole thing and abided by your plan.

You may a few more rules to your list, but make it simple, concise, actionable and specific. Too complicated of a plan, and you might be overwhelmed. Too simple, and you might ignore it.
